summary: Arthur G. Vaivada was a CIA agent who requested reassignment from Cuba in June 1958. He is also known as Ross L. Crozier, and documents related to him are associated with Project HUMANOID in Costa Rica. The documents cover a range of topics including his performance evaluations, contract extensions, operational clearance requests, and suitability for contact agent work. His file also includes a historical listing of organizations identified by the Attorney General deemed subversive. He was involved in operations in Mexico and Havana.
key_connections: Chief of the Western Hemisphere Division (WHD)
significance: The significance of Arthur G. Vaivada in the JFK context is not explicitly stated in the provided documents. However, his involvement in CIA operations in Cuba and Costa Rica during the late 1950s and his association with Project HUMANOID could be relevant to understanding the broader context of CIA activities during that period, which may have indirect connections to events surrounding the JFK assassination.
